The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a topic of intense current interest. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical characterization of the category of Hilbert space operators, which is the mathematical foundation of quantum mechanics. Our characterization is based on a set of axioms that are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This approach is a significant advance over previous attempts to provide a categorical foundation of quantum theory, which were based on the assumption that quantum mechanics is a theory in the category of Hilbert spaces. Our approach is also more general than previous ones, in that it applies to any category of operators that is closed under taking adjoints and invertible elements. Our characterization provides a precise mathematical justification for the physical intuition that the category of Hilbert space operators is the appropriate mathematical foundation of quantum theory.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present the first comparative genomic analysis of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results show that myxozoans are cnidarians and are a sister taxon to the less reduced cnidarian parasite, P. hydriforme. In addition, we find that myxozoans have one of the smallest reported animal genomes and that they lack key elements of signaling pathways and transcriptional factors important for multicellular development. These results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and replicate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to block nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We found that SARS-CoV-2 ORF6 protein localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its ability to antagonize the antiviral action of IFN. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. However, the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 channel. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet the needs of the growing urban population. This will require increasing the area under cultivation and yield gains. However, the optimum growing temperature for maize is close to the current global mean temperature, and the projected warming will increase the variability of yields. We quantify the magnitude of this increase and its consequences for global maize production and trade. Our results show that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year increases from 0% to 7% under 2 °C warming and to 86% under 4 °C warming. This will have important consequences for the global food system and the millions of people living in extreme poverty. Our results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level plant consumption. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant African LMH species. We found that, despite being similar in body size and proportional grass consumption, these species differed in diet composition, and that dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our approach could be used to quantify diet partitioning in herbivores across taxa and ecosystems. This would be important because, in many ecosystems, LMH are the dominant grazers and browsers, and their diversity is linked to plant diversity.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, which are the backbone of the US economy. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses anticipate difficulties accessing the CARES Act programs, which may exacerbate the crisis.

Plastic debris is a major environmental concern in the open ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, mostly due to the size-selective sinks of millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. This study also highlights the need for a better understanding of the global distribution of microplastic debris.

We determined ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The ages range from 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System 4.6 Ga ago. A majority of the grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. Longer lifetimes are expected for large grains. We estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. The grains were part of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The large difference in nuclear recoil loss of cosmic ray spallation products 3He and 21Ne enabled us to estimate that the irradiated objects in the interstellar medium were up to 30 times larger than the analyzed grains. The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources. This study provides a comprehensive reconstruction of the evolution of the global fishing fleet and its impact on the marine environment. It is the first to disaggregate the data into artisanal and industrial sectors and to estimate engine power. It also provides a comprehensive analysis of the impact of the global fleet on the marine environment. The study is based on a unique dataset that will be of interest to researchers and policy makers. The dataset is available for download.

The ability to reproduce is a fundamental characteristic of all living organisms. In this study, we investigate the factors that influence reproductive output in mammals. We find that the most important factor is the mother’s metabolic power. This finding is important because it suggests that the evolution of mammals was driven by the evolution of the mother’s metabolism rather than the evolution of the environment. This finding also has implications for the evolution of all forms of allonursing, which is a common form of maternal care in mammals. Our results suggest that the evolution of allonursing may have been driven by the evolution of the mother’s metabolism. This study also highlights the importance of comparative approaches in understanding the evolution of animal behavior and biology. (Show more)

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, its monomeric and oligomeric forms, and with neuroprotective effects in the substantia nigra. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA and other α-synucleinopathies. The results also provide a rationale for the use of VX-765 in other synucleinopathies, including Parkinson’s disease. This study opens the door to the development of a new class of drugs that could be used to treat synucleinopathies.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is responsible for controlling vascular function. It is composed of a single layer of cells that are specialized to detect and respond to multiple stimuli. The endothelium is able to integrate information from multiple sources and coordinate its responses. The communication system that the endothelium uses to integrate information is poorly understood. Here, we show that the endothelium is connected in a network and that the network is small-world, a property that is associated with high efficiency in the transmission of information. The small-world network is effective for both local and global communication and is able to rapidly and robustly transmit information between cells. These findings reveal the nature of the communication system that the endothelium uses to control cardiovascular function. They also provide a model for the design of communication systems in other biological and technological systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. The COVIDcast API is our attempt to address these challenges. It provides open access to both traditional public health surveillance signals (cases, deaths, and hospitalizations) and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity, such as signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. These are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The COVIDcast API also tracks all revisions to historical data, allowing modelers to account for the frequent revisions and backfill that are common for many public health data sources. All of the data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and are the targets of many drugs. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this residue is essential for the allosteric coupling between C-type inactivation and activation gating. We have also shown that the collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter is the molecular mechanism underlying the structural changes that lead to the inversion of the allosteric coupling. Finally, we have shown that the collapse of the selectivity filter can be used to achieve closed-state inactivation. This work provides a molecular explanation for the allosteric coupling between C-type inactivation and activation gating and opens the door to the development of new drugs.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a complex ecosystem that is influenced by the host and its diet. The role of the gut microbiome in the health of herbivores is well-documented, but the mechanisms by which the microbiome regulates the host are not fully understood. This study investigates the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate the microbiome. The genomes of four representative anaerobic fungi were sequenced and analyzed, and the biosynthetic genes were identified and characterized. The results support the hypothesis that anaerobic fungi synthesize natural products and provide a foundation for future studies to investigate the role of anaerobic fungi in the regulation of the herbivore microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the mechanisms underlying the establishment of social hierarchies remain largely unknown. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a high risk of becoming subordinate in social encounters, directly influences social dominance in rats. We further identify a key role for brain energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens, a brain region involved in the regulation of social behavior, in the establishment of social hierarchy. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to design and manufacture multifunctional structures with desired mechanical responses is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a general approach to design and manufacture multifunctional structures with desired mechanical responses. It is expected to inspire the design of multifunctional structures with complex behaviors in various fields. (Simplified)

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin levels in human blood are determined by the expression of the globin genes, which are under the control of the HNF4A and BCL11A transcription factors. In this study, we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in human erythroid tissues and that its expression is developmentally regulated. IGF2BP1 silencing in adult bone marrow causes a nearly complete reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like pattern. This suggests that IGF2BP1 may play a role in the heterochronous regulation of hemoglobin levels in humans.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of cancer cell resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. We found that cancer cells with mutations in the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway, highly prevalent in human cancer, are resistant to ferroptosis. This resistance is mediated by sustained activation of mTORC1 and the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. We also found that stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1), a transcriptional target of SREBP1, mediates the ferroptosis-suppressing activity of SREBP1 by producing monounsaturated fatty acids. These findings suggest that targeting the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway in combination with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs), which are major drugs for treating hypertension. However, the mechanisms of action of LCCBs are not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) through a mechanism involving the N terminus of STIM1. Our findings have important implications for the use of LCCBs in patients with cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our findings also provide a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the actions of LCCBs and their potential adverse effects in patients. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test whether the NWFP was effective in halting the decline of older-forest–associated birds and stabilizing early-seral–associated birds. We found that the NWFP halted the decline of early-seral birds, but failed to halt the decline of older-forest–associated birds. The NWFP also failed to stabilize older-forest–associated bird populations, which continued to decline. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The approach presented here can be used to design new antibiotics against other pathogens. The design strategy is applicable to other antibiotic classes as well. Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, making it difficult to train and apply them in practice. In this work, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The proposed architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art results in several segmentation problems. The proposed architecture is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. It is also easier to parallelize, which is important for training large networks. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for many image-processing problems.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). Over the Quaternary, we observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is increasing rapidly, but the biological effects of this exposure on sleep are unknown. We compared the effects of reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) with reading a printed book in the hours before bedtime. Participants reading an LE-eBook took longer to fall asleep and had reduced evening sleepiness, reduced melatonin secretion, later timing of their circadian clock, and reduced next-morning alertness than when reading a printed book. These results demonstrate that evening exposure to an LE-eBook phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. The Younger Dryas cooling is a 1,300-y period of global climate change that is often attributed to a bolide impact. However, the impact hypothesis has been challenged by the discovery of magnetic grains and microspherules in sediments that are consistent with a terrestrial origin. We show that the magnetic grains and microspherules are not of extraterrestrial origin but are derived from a terrestrial source. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotope compositions of the magnetic grains and microspherules indicate that they are from a Grenville Province source in northeastern North America. The 187Os/188Os ratios of the magnetic grains and microspherules are consistent with a terrestrial source. The 187Os/188Os ratios of the Grenville Province source are similar to those of bulk sediments from a bolide impact site in Belgium, suggesting that the bolide impact triggered the Younger Dryas cooling.

The role of cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4) in the development of autoimmune diseases has been controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital CTLA-4–deficient mice. CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice resulted in lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. However, in contrast to congenital deficiency, this was not fatal. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of CD4+Foxp3+ Treg cells. However, T cells from CTLA-4–deficient inducible KO mice were able to adoptively transfer the diseases into T cell-deficient mice. Notably, cell transfer of thymocytes de novo produced myocarditis, otherwise not observed in donor mice depleted in adulthood. Moreover, CTLA-4 deficiency affected both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of these genes in their genomes. We propose that these genes enabled efficient digestion of plant tissues, including lignocellulose in cell walls, facilitating the evolution of uniquely specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We manipulated population size such that participants could learn from the planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Our results show that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of technology and the emergence of culture.

The apoE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) susceptibility. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk, and APOE4 is the most strongly associated allele. APOE is also a major protein in the brain, and APOE4 is associated with increased risk of AD. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses in the brain. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis, whereas APOE4 decreases it. We also found that APOE4 is associated with increased accumulation of complement component C1q in the brain, which may be due to defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes. These studies suggest that APOE4 may be associated with increased risk of AD due to defective astrocytic phagocytosis of senescent synapses, which may enhance synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis is consistent with the observation that APOE4 is associated with increased levels of C1q in the brain. These studies also suggest that APOE may be a major regulator of astrocytic function in the brain. This may have important implications for understanding the pathogenesis of AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid ball of iron that is 1,200 km in diameter and 12,000 km in radius. It is the densest part of the Earth, with a density of 13.0–13.5 g/cm3, which is 13–15 times that of water. The inner core is thought to have formed when molten iron cooled below the melting point. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We found that the bcc phase of iron has a higher nucleation rate than does the hcp phase under inner core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the origin of the Earth's inner core. (Show more)

Marijuana legalization is a current social issue, and the need to understand the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain is urgent. We investigated the effects of methylphenidate (MP), a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) in the brain, on the brain DA reactivity in marijuana abusers and controls. Compared with controls, marijuana abusers had significantly blunted responses to MP, including reduced decreases in striatal dopamine D2 receptor availability (reflecting DA increases). The attenuated responses to MP, including reduced decreases in striatal DVs, are consistent with decreased brain reactivity to the DA stimulation in marijuana abusers that might contribute to their negative emotionality (increased stress reactivity and irritability) and addictive behaviors. These findings highlight the importance of studying the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain DA reactivity. They also suggest that the brain DA reactivity might be a target for treatment of marijuana addiction.

Language is the defining feature of our species, and the brain’s processing of language is the focus of intense study. Here, we use a large, diverse set of deep learning models to understand how language is processed in the human brain. We find that the most powerful models can accurately predict neural and behavioral responses to sentences with over 90% accuracy. These models’ neural fits are strongly correlated with their accuracy on predicting which word will follow a given sentence in a text-completion task. We also find that the models’ architecture appears to contribute substantially to their neural fit. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that predictive processing may be a general principle of cognition. This principle may be important to understand in its own right, and also to inform the development of artificial intelligence.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. This paper shows that the instability of DL is not a fundamental problem, but rather a consequence of the instability of the algorithms used to train DL models. We prove that there are well-conditioned problems in scientific computing that can be solved by stable neural networks, but there are no algorithms that can train such networks. This result provides a classification theory of the conditions under which stable neural networks can be trained. We also introduce a fast iterative restarted network (FIRENET) that we prove is stable and numerically verify is fast and stable. This paper is a major step toward understanding the stability of deep learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act quickly enough, the failure of the health care system, and the failure of people to comply with social distancing measures. One of the most prominent arguments is that people’s inability to understand exponential growth is a major factor. This argument is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. However, the experiment’s critical design flaws were not noticed at the time and have only recently been brought to light. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy, or Hansen's disease, is a chronic infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae. The disease is characterized by progressive loss of sensation and disfigurement of the face and extremities. The disease is curable with multidrug therapy, but the disease is still endemic in many parts of the world. The pathogenicity of the disease is still not fully understood. We sequenced the genome of a patient from Mexico, where leprosy is endemic, and found that the pathogen is a new species, Mycobacterium lepromatosis. This study provides insights into the evolution of leprosy and the pathogenicity of the disease. (Show more)

The entanglement dynamics of interacting quantum many-body systems is a central problem in quantum science. It is also a very difficult one, as it is not amenable to analytical methods. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics of the Heisenberg spin chain can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit, which is the most difficult regime to tackle. We check our result against numerical simulations and find perfect agreement. This work provides a general framework for the entanglement dynamics of interacting quantum systems. It also paves the way for the study of entanglement in the space–time scaling limit in general.

The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in more than 5 million deaths worldwide. The only vaccine currently in clinical development, developed by the University of Oxford and AstraZeneca, is based on a chimpanzee adenovirus vector. This study describes a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine candidate, which is being developed by the University of Oxford in collaboration with the University of São Paulo. The vaccine candidate, named COVI-VAC, is based on a segment of the viral spike protein recoded with synonymous suboptimal codon pairs, thereby introducing 283 silent mutations. The vaccine candidate was shown to be highly attenuated in vitro and in vivo, and to elicit robust immune responses in hamsters. The vaccine candidate is being tested in a phase I/II clinical trial in Brazil. If successful, the vaccine candidate could be used in mass vaccination programs to combat the COVID-19 pandemic.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work also provides a framework for studying the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of other diseases. Our model can be extended to include other human ectoparasites, such as head lice (Pediculus humanus capitis), and to study the role of these vectors in the spread of diseases such as malaria. The role of TRAP1 in mitochondria has been controversial. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This work suggests that TRAP1 may be a target for cancer therapy. (Show more)

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements that mediate cell shape changes and are involved in many cellular processes. They are also disassembled by the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family of proteins. However, how ADF/cofilin disassembles actin filaments in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques, coupled to microfluidics, to monitor and quantify the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that local curvature favors severing, while tension surprisingly has no effect on cofilin binding and weakly enhances severing. Remarkably, we observe that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon cofilin binding. We propose that this ADF/cofilin-induced torque increases the severing rate constant 100-fold. A consequence of this mechanism is that cross-linked filament networks are severed by cofilin far more efficiently than nonconnected filaments. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is a major contributor to the rising epidemic of obesity in the United States. Although the effects of fructose on appetite and food intake have been studied extensively, the brain mechanisms underlying the effects of fructose versus glucose on appetite and food intake are less clear. We show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and promotes feeding behavior. These findings suggest that fructose may be a stronger appetite suppressant than previously thought. Our results also highlight the importance of controlling for the type of carbohydrate consumed in future studies of the effects of sweeteners on appetite and food intake. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, and that the population experienced a demographic growth. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, and that the population was already admixed before the arrival of the first Malagasy diaspora. Finally, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genomic diversity of Madagascar, and it will be useful for the study of the human history of the island. It will also be useful for the study of the human history of the Indian Ocean, and for the study of the human history of Africa.

We show that people’s emotions can be transferred to others via social networks. This work has implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social networks.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary targets of posttranscriptional regulation, and the vast majority of these modifications are found in the coding regions of mRNAs. However, the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis has not been well characterized. We show that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in mRNA codons can modestly alter translation speed and increase the rate of near-cognate amino acid incorporation. These findings suggest that mRNA modifications can have subtle effects on translation, and that the ribosome can encounter Ψ moieties in the course of decoding mRNA codons. Our work also reveals that Ψ can be a substrate for protein synthesis, and that the presence of Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. These findings highlight the potential for mRNA modifications to impact protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust to the influence of factors such as socioeconomic status, educational attainment, and health status. Longitudinal analyses indicate that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is a strong predictor of positive changes in these outcomes over a 4-y period. These findings suggest that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is thought to have driven the diversification of the four extant lineages of water-dwelling mammals. We test this hypothesis by examining the evolution of body size in these clades. We find that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms. Our results suggest that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the diversification of the four extant lineages of water-dwelling mammals.

The common cold virus, rhinovirus, replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. To understand the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth, we compared the transcriptional response of primary mouse airway epithelial cells infected with rhinovirus at 33 °C vs. 37 °C. We found that rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at 37 °C, and that this is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. They also suggest that rhinovirus may use the same mechanism to evade antiviral defense in the respiratory tract of humans as it does in the respiratory tract of mice. Finally, they highlight the importance of temperature in the design of vaccines and antiviral therapies for the common cold virus. (Show more)

Bacteria use a variety of sensory systems to sense the environment and respond appropriately. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface-adhesion system to sense surfaces and respond accordingly. This mechanosensory system is mediated by the type IV pili, a major surface-adhesion system of P. aeruginosa. The pili-mediated surface sensing results in a positive feedback loop that promotes long-term surface attachment and stimulates additional virulence and biofilm-inducing pathways. The pili-mediated mechanosensory system is mediated by a methyl-accepting chemotaxis protein-like protein, PilJ, which directly interacts with the pilin subunit PilA. Our findings demonstrate that type IV pili can be used as a sensor to regulate surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This mechanochemical model provides a mechanistic understanding of how bacteria use pili as a sensor to regulate surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades, and the use of insecticides in particular has been associated with a decline in aquatic biodiversity. However, the extent to which pesticides are present in surface waters and the effects on biodiversity are not well understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface waters and their effects on aquatic biodiversity. Our results show that the use of pesticides in agriculture is associated with a substantial risk to surface water biodiversity. We recommend that the use of pesticides in agriculture be reduced worldwide and that the use of newer-generation insecticides be phased out.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on human health and the global economy. The virus has also spread to animals, including white-tailed deer, which are susceptible to infection and can transmit the disease to other deer. We report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in deer, which could have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. Our findings highlight the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the ecology and evolution of SARS-CoV-2, as well as the role of animals in the spread of the virus. This will require a coordinated effort between human and animal health researchers to develop a One Health approach to managing the pandemic.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the causes of this trend and the challenges that need to be addressed. We find that the benefits of hydropower are overestimated and the costs underestimated. We also find that the environmental and social impacts of dams are not being adequately considered in the decision-making process. We propose solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is the primary component of amyloid plaques that are the hallmark of the disease. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation and progression of AD is still controversial. Here, we show that Aβ-burdened neurons are the primary source of inflammatory factors that trigger the immune response in the brain. This neuron-specific inflammatory response may precede the formation of Aβ plaques and tau tangles, and may be a key factor in the pathogenesis of AD. Our findings have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for AD.

The domestication of the chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most important events in human history. However, the earliest evidence for its economic use is still missing. We present a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and economically important in the ancient world. Our results suggest that the earliest evidence for economic use of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. This gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study provides new insights into the history of the domestication and use of chickens. (Less)

The folding of large proteins is a major unsolved problem in biochemistry. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein that folds in two steps. The first step is a fast collapse into a heterogeneous state, which is followed by a slower formation of a native-like folding intermediate. The intermediate is the obligatory step on the folding pathway and contains the sites of three previously reported destabilizing mutations. The intermediate is also the site of a second, slower step that forms the native state. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. The results also suggest that the fast collapse into a heterogeneous state is a general feature of protein folding. (Show more)

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress and have been shown to function as precursors to RNA caps. In bacteria, the predominant decapping enzyme, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable accumulation of alarmones. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is normally inactive in the presence of disulfide bonds, becomes active in the presence of alarmones. We also show that RppH decapsulates alarmones by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to decapsulate other RNAs. This enzyme recognizes alarmones by a mechanism that is unique in the family of pyrophosphohydrolases, and it preferentially removes the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, from the 5′ end of the RNA. This unusual mechanism of decapping alarmones could have major consequences for the reprogramming of gene expression during disulfide stress.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and morbidity. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease sepsis-induced immunosuppression. We found that citrulline, an amino acid derived from arginine, was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing sepsis-induced Treg and MDSC expansion. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides a rationale for the use of citrulline in the treatment of other diseases in which arginine levels are low, such as cancer. This is an important step toward the development of a new therapeutic strategy for sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We show that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics, where systems spontaneously reach a critical state. SOC systems are characterized by the presence of a power-law distribution of activity times, and the absence of external control. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with self-organized criticality (SOC) behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and thermal management. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities, and it is unclear how to control them. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by applying strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized by applying tensile strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. Our findings are also relevant to the development of diamond-based sensors and devices. Our work provides a new way to control the electronic and optical properties of diamond. The discovery of antimicrobial peptides in plants and animals has led to the development of a new class of fungicides. However, the structural basis of their antifungal activity and the molecular mechanisms of action are not well understood. Here, we report the crystal structure of a 36-residue NCR peptide from Medicago truncatula, which exhibits potent antifungal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. We also show that this peptide binds to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro and penetrates fungal cell walls and germlings, causing cell death. These results provide insights into the structural basis of antifungal activity and the mode of action of this class of peptides. This work also demonstrates the potential of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This is a major step forward in the development of a new class of plant-derived fungicides. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely that the female reproductive tract makes contributions to the development of the male reproductive system. However, the extent of such contributions is largely unknown. Here, we use proteomics and isotopic labeling to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that the female reproductive tract makes substantial contributions to the sperm proteome, and we identify a number of female-derived proteins that are enriched in processes associated with energy metabolism. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the viral component of the microbiome, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study overcomes this barrier by analyzing thousands of publicly available metagenomic datasets. The resulting database, Microbiome-Scale Metagenomic Database of Human-Associated Viruses (MIMDMAV), contains over 45,000 unique human-associated virus taxa, with over 100 million viral sequences. This database will enable the study of the human virome and its impact on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the Earth’s climate system. However, the ACI is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), for simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties. The instrument is capable of measuring aerosol and cloud properties with high spatial and temporal resolution. We demonstrate the instrument’s capability to investigate aerosol–cloud interactions. The observations show that the aerosol loading has no discernible effect on the liquid water path, but increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature history of Earth is a key factor in understanding the origin and evolution of life. The isotopic record of the paleotemperatures of the oceans, however, has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes derived from light-requiring prokaryotic and eukaryotic phototrophs having widely separated fossil-based divergence ages. The ancestral environmental temperatures thereby determined for these photic-zone organisms––shown in modern taxa to correlate strongly with NDK thermostability––are inferred to reflect ancient surface-environment paleotemperatures. Our results suggest that Earth's surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are the main ion conduits in cells and are regulated by multiple mechanisms. The K+ channel BK channel is a well-known example of a channel that does not show C-type inactivation, a common mechanism of inactivation in other K+ channels. We found that BK channels show slow C-type inactivation/recovery that is closed state-dependent and that its rates and extents inversely correlate with channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of K+ channel gating and inactivation. (Show more)

Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide and is responsible for more deaths than any other parasitic disease. The Plasmodium parasite uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and initiate disease. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses its erythrocyte-binding antigen, EBA175, to alter the biophysical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This work challenges the current paradigm of malaria invasion and suggests that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion. This work has implications for the development of antimalarial drugs and may lead to the design of new drugs that target the parasite’s ability to alter the biophysical properties of the host cell. Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and thermal management. However, it is brittle and difficult to process. Here, we show that diamond can be demetallized reversibly through reversible strain engineering. We demonstrate that diamond can be completely metallized, solely under mechanical strain without phonon instability, so that its electronic bandgap fully vanishes. This work offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. It also provides a general strategy for strain engineering of other materials. This work is expected to advance the development of diamond-based devices and applications. (Show more)

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. The impact of low humidity on host defense against influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have implications for understanding the impact of climate change on influenza transmission and disease outcome. (Show more)

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, this description is based on a model of language that is not supported by neurophysiological evidence. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the construction of a sentence is consistent with a model in which each word is merged into a phrase, and that this merge operation applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results suggest that the brain uses a bottom-up parser to identify the boundaries between phrases, and provide initial intracranial evidence for the reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the brain’s processing of language and may have broader implications for the way we think about the structure of language in general.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that regulates cell fate decisions and tissue patterning. Axin is a key component that mediates the inhibitory signal from the plasma membrane to the nucleus. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates, Axin1 and Axin2, are functionally redundant, but they are differentially regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation may be used to control the responsiveness of the two forms of Axin in different tissues. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This study also provides a method to study the regulation of redundant genes in vertebrates. This study also provides a method to study the regulation of redundant genes in vertebrates.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that controls feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes animals to eat vigorously, and this effect can be blocked by dopamine antagonists. Here we show that LH stimulation-induced eating is mediated by a circuit that includes the ventral tegmental area (VTA), substantia nigra pars reticulata, and locus coeruleus. This circuit is important for promoting overeating, as lesions of these neurons block the effect of LH stimulation. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to fix nitrogen in the soil is a key trait for plants to acquire. However, the use of nitrogen-fixing bacteria in agriculture is limited by the need to apply large amounts of fertilizer, which is both costly and unsustainable. Here, we demonstrate a method to control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the soil, using a plant-derived signal. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This approach could be used to develop sustainable agriculture systems that are more resilient to climate change. (Show more)

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest and is under threat from deforestation. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are widely used to monitor and mitigate deforestation, but the effectiveness of these alerts in deterring deforestation is unknown. We study a community-based monitoring program that uses remote-sensed deforestation alerts to identify deforestation and incentivizes community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the program’s small sample size and the difficulty of attributing deforestation to the program. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to detect and localize sounds, which is essential for survival. The auditory organs of animals are all part of the body, and the size of the auditory organs is constrained by the size of the body. However, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear by outsourcing its hearing to its web. The spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to detect and localize the source of an incoming acoustic wave. The spider’s web is not only extremely sensitive but also extremely flexible and can be regenerated after damage. This provides unique features for studying acoustic sensing and design of acoustic flow detectors. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides insights into the evolution of hearing and the design of acoustic devices. This work also provides a unique model system for studying the regenerative healing of the auditory system. (show more)

The health and climate impacts of air pollution and aerosols are difficult to disentangle. We show that removing fossil-fuel-related emissions of greenhouse gases and aerosols can save millions of lives and restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns. This would also limit global warming to 2 °C, and reduce the warming from aerosols to 1.5 °C. However, the benefits are limited by the persistence of pollution particles, which can persist for decades. We show that a simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane can moderate the warming from aerosols. Our results indicate that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic has resulted in over 3 million deaths worldwide and continues to cause severe illness and death. The global distribution of COVID-19 vaccines has been uneven, and many low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) have been left behind. We report the design and synthesis of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is well-suited for large-scale production and elicits high-affinity antibodies in mice. This protein can be used to generate vaccines for LMICs, which will help to ensure equitable access to COVID-19 vaccines. This work also highlights the importance of designing vaccines that can be produced in large quantities, as this will be critical for LMICs to access these vaccines. The role of the ALK/ALKALS receptor–ligand pair in neural crest development is unknown. We show that zebrafish ALKALS activate zebrafish ALK/ALKALS in vivo and in vitro. We further show that loss of ALK/ALKALS causes ectopic iridophore development and loss of iridophores, respectively. These results provide evidence that ALK/ALKALS are involved in neural crest development in vivo. Our findings have implications for the role of ALK/ALKALS in human cancer.

The emergence of plague, a disease that has plagued humanity for millennia, is a complex process that has been poorly understood due to a lack of genomic data from the early stages of its evolution. Here, we present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age (5,000 to 2,500 y BP) across Eurasia. Our results show that the Y. pestis lineage that gave rise to the plague pandemic in the 13th century CE was already present in Europe and the Near East during this period. We also find that the plague pathogen diversified rapidly during this time, with the emergence of a flea-adapted form of the pathogen in Iberia. These data provide insights into the early stages of plague’s evolution and its spread across Eurasia. They also highlight the importance of studying ancient genomes to understand the origins of diseases that have had a profound impact on human history. (Show more)

This work examines the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, we find that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a critical issue for the sustainability of global food production. In the United States, the conversion of grassland to cropland has led to massive losses of SOC to the atmosphere. However, the efficacy of soil health management practices in sequestering SOC on grassland-derived Mollisols remains highly uncertain. We show that soil health management practices that incorporate perennial pastures and livestock can sequester SOC and increase the use of soil carbon by the microbial community. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon and highlight the importance of integrating livestock into agricultural systems to achieve climate-smart agriculture. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify risk factors associated with spillover and used this to rank the spillover potential of 887 viruses from 74,635 animals. We validated the framework using data from 509,721 samples from 74,635 animals, and identified 12 viruses with the highest risk of spillover. The SpillOver platform provides a living, interactive database that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is often used as a cue for pollinator attraction, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We identify three enzymes that are necessary or sufficient for the production of the red pigment, and show that the same three enzymatic activities are required for the production of the yellow nectar of a distantly related plant. These findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait that is likely to be favored by selection for pollinator attraction.

The genetic structure of modern Europeans is strongly correlated with geography, but the processes that shaped it are still debated. We present a case study of a population of 5th/6th century AD individuals from southern Germany, who exhibit a high degree of genetic heterogeneity. We show that this heterogeneity is not due to admixture, but rather to a high degree of female migration from diverse geographic regions. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results indicate that the processes that shaped the genetic structure of modern Europeans were not only driven by migration from outside the continent, but also by complex processes occurring within Europe itself.

The receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5 were investigated. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS coronavirus, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. First, whereas MERS-CoV prefers human DPP4 over bat DPP4 as its receptor, HKU4 shows the opposite trend. Second, in the absence of exogenous proteases, both MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes mediate pseudovirus entry into bat cells, whereas only MERS-CoV spike, but not HKU4 spike, mediates pseudovirus entry into human cells. Thus, MERS-CoV, but not HKU4, has adapted to use human cells for efficient human cell entry, contributing to the enhanced pathogenesis of MERS-CoV in humans. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronav

The ability to rapidly identify pathogens in resource-scarce settings is critical to mitigating epidemics. We used a global cloud-based platform to sequence the pathogen RNA of 489 febrile patients in Cambodia. We identified vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers. We found that chikungunya virus presaged a national outbreak of more than 6,000 cases. Pathogen-agnostic mNGS investigation of febrile persons in resource-scarce settings is feasible and revealing of a diverse pathogen landscape. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be used to identify pathogens that are not detected by current diagnostic methods.
