The human genome is replicated in a complex process that requires multiple proteins to assemble and function. One of these proteins is proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA), which is essential for DNA replication and repair. PCNA is a sliding clamp that facilitates DNA unwinding and strand exchange. In order to replicate the lagging strand template, DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) must bind to PCNA and form a holoenzyme. We developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the pol δ holoenzyme is remarkably stable and maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA at a DNA lesion. This work provides a unique perspective on the structure and function of the pol δ holoenzyme and the implications for eukaryotic DNA replication. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can be evolved to catalyze the replication of other RNA molecules, but the fidelity of this process has not been demonstrated. Here, we report the evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work represents a major step toward the realization of the RNA world. (Show more)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. The clinical characteristics of COVID-19 are still unclear. We found that the patients with severe or critical COVID-19 had high levels of interleukin 6 and a large number of immune cells, which may cause the inflammatory storm. Tocilizumab, which targets interleukin 6, can reduce the levels of interleukin 6 and inflammatory factors, and improve the clinical symptoms.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess is toxic to cells. The ability of fungi to sequester copper is well established, but the role of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis is unknown. We report the discovery of a fungal natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and impacts cellular copper content. We also demonstrate that xanthocillin-derived isocyanide metabolites have antimicrobial properties and that these properties are dependent on copper. These results suggest that fungal natural products may play a role in copper homeostasis and interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the role of natural products in fungal physiology and interactions with other microbes. (Show more)

The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature polymorph of SiO2, on Mars is surprising because it is not a common mineral in the Martian crust. Tridymite is commonly associated with silicic volcanism, and the presence of silicic volcanism in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment can account for the tridymite, cristobalite, feldspar, and any residual high-SiO2 glass in a cogenetic detrital assemblage at Marias Pass. Opaline silica could form during diagenesis from high-SiO2 glass, as amorphous precipitated silica, or as a residue of acidic leaching in the sediment source region or at Marias Pass. The amorphous mixed-cation salts and oxides and possibly the crystalline magnetite (otherwise detrital) are primary precipitates and/or their diagenesis products derived from multiple infiltrations of aqueous solutions having variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities. The presence of tridymite on Mars is significant because it provides a new mineral phase for the study of the Martian crust and because it is a potential target for future exploration.

Frost damage is a major threat to plant productivity and a major cause of economic losses in agriculture and forestry. The geographic distribution of frost events is poorly understood, and the evolutionary impact of frost on plants is not well documented. We use a large dataset of common garden experiments to show that the geographic distribution of frost events is linked to the leaf-out and leaf-freezing resistance of woody plants. We show that the resistance strategies of plants are adapted to the geographic distribution of frost events, and that these strategies are likely to change in the future. Our findings have important implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a heterogeneous subset of CD4+ T cells that play a central role in the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental pathways that give rise to the different subsets of Th17 cells are not well understood. Here, we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and the transcription factor T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, we show that Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. This plasticity may contribute to the development of inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, which are the key cells for voluntary muscle control. The disease is caused by mutations in many genes, but the cause of the disease in most patients is unknown. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients’ fibroblasts, which can be used to study the disease and test potential treatments. This method will enable the study of the disease in many more patients and greatly accelerate the development of treatments. (Read more)

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors is critical for pathogen colonization and development. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota are poorly understood. We now demonstrate that the tick antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp) is expressed in the gut and modifies the microbiota to more efficiently colonize the tick. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the arthropod microbiome and may have implications for vector-borne disease transmission. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important and enigmatic transitions in vertebrate evolution. The discovery of a basal member of the clade Pygostylia (birds with a short tail ending in a compound bone termed “pygostyle”) adds important information about the origin of the modern avian bauplan. This study describes a new species of early pygostylian bird, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of water vapor. We show here that water vapor has a positive feedback on climate, and that this feedback is stronger in the stratosphere than in the troposphere. This implies that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This is important because the stratosphere is currently a region of strong climate change. We estimate the strength of this feedback to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. This feedback is also important because it is positive, meaning that it increases with increasing temperature. This implies that the climate system is more sensitive to increases in greenhouse gases than it is to decreases in greenhouse gases. This is important because it means that the climate system is more sensitive to the emissions of greenhouse gases than it is to the removal of greenhouse gases. This is a very important result, and it has implications for the future of our planet. It also has implications for the future of our civilization.

Vertebrates have evolved a variety of colors, from red to blue, to camouflage themselves from predators and prey. In some species, the color of the animal is determined by the presence of a pigment, such as melanin or carotenoids. In others, the color is determined by the presence of a protein, such as the green color of the frog skin. This study describes the molecular basis of the green color of frogs, and shows that the green color of frogs is determined by a protein that binds biliverdin, a pigment that is formed when hemoglobin is degraded. This study also shows that the green color of frogs is determined by a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study provides a molecular basis for the evolution of the green color of frogs, and introduces a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a feature of many solid tumors, and is associated with increased rates of tumor growth and metastasis. However, the mechanisms that regulate the tumor microenvironment in response to hypoxia are not well understood. We report that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the HIF-1α and HIF-2α pathways, and is required for the induction of breast cancer stem cell (BCSC) properties. Thus, ALKBH5 expression in response to hypoxia may be a mechanism that regulates the tumor microenvironment in response to hypoxia. This may be important for the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. (Show more)

The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. The Latin term abortivum in many sources has led some scholars to suggest that fetal calves or sheep skins were used. Others have argued that it would not be possible to sustain herds if so many pocket Bibles were produced from fetal skins, arguing instead for unexpected alternatives, such as rabbit. Here, we report a simple and objective method using standard conservation treatments to identify the animal origin of parchment. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals; however, we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding the causes and consequences of extinction and recovery. We present a precise age model for the Permian-Triassic boundary based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds in China. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly volatile during the extinction and recovery, and the latter was punctuated by multiple episodes of ecosystem reorganization. These results provide a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. They also provide a basis for testing the relative roles of rate-dependent and threshold processes in the extinction and recovery of the end-Permian fauna. The results are important for understanding the causes and consequences of extinction and recovery in the fossil record. They also have implications for understanding the causes and consequences of mass extinction in the Earth’s history.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a member of the orphan nuclear receptor superfamily and plays important roles in various biological processes, such as cancer and metabolism. However, the function of RORα in the intestine is not well understood. Here, we report that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also find that RORα is required for the control of intestinal inflammation in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Our results suggest that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most common substitution in circulating virus strains and has been shown to increase virus infectivity in vitro. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike in the presence and absence of the D614G mutation and show that the mutant spike is in a more open conformation that may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent fusion. These results provide insight into the mechanism of the D614G mutation and may inform the development of vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, disproportionately affecting Black and Latino Americans. We estimate that the pandemic will result in a 1.13-y reduction in life expectancy at birth and a 0.87-y reduction at age 65 y for the total US population. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y. These findings underscore the importance of addressing structural inequalities in order to achieve health equity. (Show more)

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry and are fundamental to the understanding of the chemical world. In this work, we show that pressure can change the chemical properties of atoms, and that these changes can be predicted by a simple model. This work has implications for the understanding of the chemical world under pressure, and for the development of new materials.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, but the implications for the global carbon cycle are poorly understood. We quantify the effects of climate and human demography on fire activity and carbon emissions, using a coupled global climate–fire–carbon cycle model. We find that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. However, recent and predicted future reductions in fire activity may enhance land carbon uptake and corresponding to offsetting ∼5 to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels. This potentially reduces warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. We show that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, although with some risk of more extreme fires regionally. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the global carbon cycle and the need to consider the effects of climate, fire, and humans in future projections of climate change.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan, chitin, to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel cycle that is synchronized with the host’s circadian clock. We also show that the glycan is required for the persistence of the symbiont, and that its catabolism modulates the pH of the symbiotic organ, which in turn affects the luminescence of the symbiont. These results suggest that the provision of nutrients to symbionts may be a more general mechanism for regulating the stability of animal–microbe associations. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We first identify a set of vectors (“discourse atoms”) that provide a sparse representation of an embedding space. Discourse atoms can be interpreted as latent topics; through a generative model, atoms map onto distributions over words. We can also infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). The NVDRS summarizes violent death incidents with structured variables and unstructured narratives. We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. Motivated by known patterns in suicide and homicide by gender and recent research on gender biases in semantic space, we identify the gender bias of our topics (e.g., a topic about pain medication is feminine). We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. The second plague pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the second plague pandemic and the role of climate in its spread. (Less)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important ecosystem engineers. They are also a valuable food resource for many marine animals. However, the population-level impacts of asteroid wasting disease on these animals are poorly understood. Here, we show that a densovirus is the likely cause of the wasting disease and that it is transmitted vertically and horizontally. This study highlights the importance of viral diseases in shaping the structure and function of marine ecosystems.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of blood cancer, and the prognosis of AML patients is poor. The identification of AML stem cells is a major challenge in the treatment of AML, and there is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in the population. Finally, we found that the genetic structure is not only a consequence of admixture but also of the geography of Madagascar, suggesting that the island was settled by different groups of people. These results help to understand the history of Madagascar and provide a framework for the study of the human population in the Indian Ocean. (Show more)

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that increases dehydrogenase activity. We found that the protein interferes with the ability of the RNA to repress carbon utilization genes. The RNA and protein compete for the same translation initiation site, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This is an example of a protein that is encoded by an RNA and that interferes with the ability of the RNA to regulate its target genes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and are often not used in agricultural decision-making. We show how to convert the original categorical crop ratings into a continuous probabilistic variable that can be used to monitor crop status and predict crop yields. We demonstrate the utility of this approach by showing how it can be used to provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our approach can be used to monitor crop status and provide early warnings of crop anomalies, and can be easily extended to other crops and countries. This approach can be used to monitor crop status and provide early warnings of crop anomalies, and can be easily extended to other crops and countries.

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that involves the ability to integrate and store information in working memory. The dominant view is that this is achieved through sustained, elevated neural activity. Here we propose an alternative account where memory is supported by intrinsic plasticity that downregulates neuronal firing rates. We show that this adaptive change in excitability can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community. However, the majority of studies have been conducted at a single site, limiting our ability to draw conclusions about the response of soil respiration to climate change. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture measurements, totaling over 3,800 observations. Our analysis reveals that soil respiration does not increase in response to experimental warming in all biomes, contrary to the results from single-site studies. Moreover, our data provide evidence that soil respiration may decrease with increasing temperature in some biomes, suggesting that the response of soil respiration to climate change may be more complex than previously thought. This study adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important events in the history of life. It is also one of the most challenging evolutionary questions in biology. The molecular signature of this transition is still poorly understood. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. This model can be extended to other types of parasites and may help to understand the molecular signature of the transition to parasitism in general. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of water-scarce regions to climate change. We use a high-resolution climate model to show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. They also highlight the importance of regional climate models in assessing the impact of climate change on drought risk. (Show more)

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the so-called “cyclase” reaction, is the rate-limiting step in the pathway. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, BchE, to catalyze this reaction, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria use a diiron protein, AcsF. The latter is a subunit of a larger enzyme, the O2-dependent cyclase. We show that Ycf54 is a subunit of the O2-dependent cyclase in oxygenic phototrophs, and that different classes of the enzyme exist based on their requirement for an additional subunit. These data delineate three classes of O2-dependent cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as EAE. Apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1) is a mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase that has been implicated in neuroinflammation. However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we generated conditional knockout (CKO) mice that lack ASK1 in T cells, dendritic cells, microglia/macrophages, microglia, or astrocytes, to assess the roles of ASK1 during experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE). We found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a greater proinflammatory role in the later stage. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest on record and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that the probability of drought has increased if precipitation deficits occur when conditions are warm. We also find that anthropogenic forcings have increased the probability that dry precipitation years are also warm. These findings suggest that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California. This work also highlights the importance of considering the effects of climate change on the probability of drought. The probability of drought is increasing in many regions of the world, and our findings suggest that this trend will likely continue. Autism is a complex disorder with a multifactorial etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. As an alternative approach, extensive efforts have been devoted to identifying the convergence of the targets and functions of the autism-risk genes to facilitate mapping out causal paths. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and suggests that the forgetting process is a potential therapeutic target for autism. (Show more)

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of intracellular Ca2+ signaling, and mutations in the pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 cause severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and loss-of-function mutations in the ORAI1 pore-forming protein that cause hematological abnormalities. We also identify a new mechanism of ORAI1 gain-of-function, which is relevant for the phenotype of patients with Stormorken syndrome. Our findings expand our understanding of the molecular basis of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, and suggest new therapeutic approaches for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease and Parkinson’s disease. In these diseases, the spread of aggregates is thought to be a major contributor to disease pathology. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on the internalization of aggregates and the ability of neurons to release them. These results demonstrate that the mechanisms underlying the spread of aggregates are conserved between Drosophila and mammals and provide a platform for studying the mechanisms of spreading in neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

The immune system of bats is considered to be highly specialized and immune privileged, which is believed to be a key factor in the maintenance of a healthy microbial community in the bat gut. However, the immunosuppressant protein (MTX) identified in this study is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and is highly stable in the presence of digestive enzymes. MTX is a potent inhibitor of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H), which is responsible for the hydrolysis of the lipid mediator leukotriene B4 (LTB4). MTX is also a potent inhibitor of the proinflammatory proteases plasmin, trypsin, and elastase. MTX is therefore a potent immunomodulator that can inhibit the host immune response and facilitate viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into the immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key metabolic node in the biosynthesis of purine nucleotides. Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT that blocks tumor growth in vivo. We also report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT that blocks tumor growth in vivo. We show that the one-carbon donor formate rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This work provides a foundation for the development of a small-molecule therapeutic targeting the metabolic vulnerabilities of cancer. (Show more)

The presence of proteins that are supersaturated in the brain and spinal cord of patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) suggests that these proteins are prone to aggregation. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a mechanism for the formation of inclusion bodies in ALS and suggests that the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord may be a common feature of neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystals can be used to control the interactions between atoms, allowing for the creation of a variety of quantum states. The photonic crystals can also be used to control the emission of light from the atoms, allowing for the creation of a variety of states of light. The earliest known angiosperms are aquatic plants that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water. The discovery of Montsechia, a plant from the early Cretaceous, raises questions about the very early diversification of the Ceratophyllum clade and the role of aquatic habitats in the early evolution of angiosperms.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) from Eurasia and Greenland. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is dated to ∼12.6 kya. We also find that the recombination event that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. These results emphasize the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. They also show that ancient viral sequences can be used to date the emergence of viruses, which is important for understanding the emergence of pathogens and the spread of pandemics. This study

Sea level is rising at a rate of 2.9 ± 0.4 mm/y, and this rate is expected to continue for decades to come. However, the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and this acceleration is not explained by the rate of global warming. We find that the acceleration of sea level rise is consistent with a climate-change–driven acceleration of 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2. This acceleration is not explained by changes in the rate of global warming, and it is not explained by changes in the rate of ocean heat uptake. We conclude that the climate system is not in thermal equilibrium with the atmosphere, and we discuss the implications of this result for climate science and climate policy.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain prevalence has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not limited to pain, but is part of a broader trend of declining social status and increasing inequality.

The ability to characterize the structure and dynamics of enzyme active sites is critical to understanding how they function. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. This integrated approach provides atomic-resolution characterization of the protonation states of the ionizable sites on the cofactor, substrate, and catalytic side chains as well as the location and orientation of crystallographic waters within the active site. The detailed picture of structure and reactivity that emerges from this work highlights the fate of the L-serine hydroxyl leaving group and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. This work also provides a detailed description of the binding of the unnatural substrate benzimidazole, which is unable to initiate the subsequent bond formation step. The chemically detailed, three-dimensional structure from NMR-assisted crystallography is key to understanding why benzimidazole does not react, while indole does. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme function. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus that emerged in 2012. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high case fatality rate (25–85%) highlights the need for effective antiviral therapies. Remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, was shown to inhibit SARS-CoV replication in vitro and in vivo, and was tested in a mouse model of SARS-CoV infection. Here, we show that prophylactic and therapeutic treatment with remdesivir in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection resulted in a strong clinical benefit, with a reduction in clinical signs, reduced virus replication in the lungs, and decreased presence and severity of lung lesions. These data support the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial setting, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great benefit to the global community. (Show more)

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms that regulate the timing and quantity of nutrient delivery are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan, chitin, to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, only at dusk, when the symbiotic organ is at its most stable. We also show that the glycan is required for the persistence of the symbionts in the organ, and that the glycan catabolism modulates the environment of the symbionts’ habitat. These results suggest that the timing and quantity of nutrient delivery may be regulated by the host to maintain the stability of the symbiosis. This study highlights the importance of glycans in the regulation of symbiosis. (Show more)

The suspension rate in US schools is 10 times higher than it was in 1992. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt a more empathic mindset about student misbehavior, which can reduce suspension rates. It also shows that this mindset can be sustained over time. Finally, it shows that a brief, online intervention can reduce suspension rates in the field. These findings have implications for the future of US schools.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA lesions that can interfere with the normal function of the genome. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. We also identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. (Show more)

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first S protein cleavages. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses trafficked past cell-surface proteases and into endosomes, whereas precleaved viruses used endosomal proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry. Uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change, and the global population is expected to increase by 2 billion people by 2050. The food choices of the majority of people in high-income countries are a major driver of this unsustainable trajectory. This study demonstrates that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large-scale catering operation can have a significant impact on meal selection. The results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering operations could have a significant impact on meal selection, and therefore on the environment and population health. This approach could be easily implemented in other settings.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex environment that is remodeled in cancer cells. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to reveal how the surfaceome is remodeled in a collection of six different oncogenes, including EGFR, HER2, KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal electoral consequences.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has led to more than 30 million confirmed cases and over 900,000 deaths worldwide. The virus has been shown to evade the host immune response, and it is possible that this evasion is mediated by the accessory protein ORF8. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 at 2.04-Å resolution. We show that ORF8 can form a unique large-scale assembly, and that this assembly is specific to SARS-CoV-2. These results provide insight into the mechanisms by which SARS-CoV-2 may evade the host immune response and may inform the development of antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cerebral cortex to trigger the release of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) from astrocytes, which increases the water permeability of the blood–brain barrier and causes cerebral edema. This study provides a mechanism for the pathogenesis of cerebral edema in hypoxia and may lead to the development of new therapies for this condition. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is of great importance in modern data analysis. It arises when we have a large dataset and wish to find associations in it. The fact that we have “cherry-picked” the data means that we must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we find. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We show how these methods can be used to address the challenge of selective inference.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the formation of vascular networks. However, the generation of ECs from nonvascular cells is still a challenge. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). ETV2-mediated conversion of fibroblasts into ETVECs is independent of the expression of hematopoietic transcription factors, and the ETVECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in mice. Furthermore, ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. (Show more)

The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as ligands of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has led to the identification of a new class of RTK ligands. Here, we show that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also demonstrate that the augmentor ligands are essential for embryonic iridophore development and adult body coloration. Importantly, these processes are entirely mediated by Ltk and not by Alk. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a foundation for understanding the physiological role of Alk and Ltk in vivo. It also provides a model system for studying the role of ligand-specific RTKs in development and disease. This work also provides a foundation for understanding the role of ligand-specific RTKs in development and disease.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Accumulating evidence indicates that STING plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cells remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis showed that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, the assay for transposase-accessible chromatin with high-throughput sequencing (ATAC-seq) and cleavage under targets and tagmentation (CUT&Tag) analyses suggested that Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO mice. Together, these data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned ST

Influenza A viruses are responsible for an annual influenza epidemic and occasional severe pandemic. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. We identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments that favors their preferential packaging into each virion. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and nonspecifically decreases the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This work provides a molecular understanding of the selective packaging mechanism of influenza A virus. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in blood vessels. The atheroprone flow environment is a critical risk factor for the development of atherosclerosis. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. In this study, we found that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is a key event in the disturbed flow-induced induction of proatherosclerotic phenotypes in endothelial cells. We also found that statin, an antiatherosclerotic drug, inhibits YAP/TAZ activation to suppress the disturbed flow-induced atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion development. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the disturbed flow-induced atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion development and provides a potential therapeutic target for the prevention and treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen dramatically in recent decades, and climate change has likely contributed to this trend. In this study, we show that human activities have greatly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, and that human-caused wildfires disproportionately occur in regions where people live and work. These findings highlight the need for increased management of human-caused wildfires to reduce the risk of wildfire to people and property.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to measure the physical changes in any city over time. We hope that this work will inspire further research on the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and eco-friendly pest control method. However, the molecular targets of these plant-derived compounds in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel that mediates the avoidance behavior of scorpions toward Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and also demonstrates the evolutionary adaptation of TRP channels in arthropod evolution. It should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. (Show more)

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid and the eclipse phase for ZIKV is most likely short. We also show that antiviral treatment can be effective in reducing the peak viral load and shortening the time to undetectable viral load. However, the treatment must be given early in the infection to be effective. The results presented here can be used to inform the design of clinical trials of antiviral treatment for ZIKV infection. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that occurs when corals shed their symbiotic algae, resulting in the bright color of the coral tissue. This color change is a defense mechanism that allows corals to survive the stressor, but it is also a symptom of a breakdown of the coral–algae symbiosis. We show that the metabolic interactions between the coral host and its algal symbionts are a key factor in the breakdown of the symbiosis. We demonstrate that the coral host is unable to maintain the metabolic homeostasis of the symbiosis, which is a consequence of altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. (Show more)

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a barrier to the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the immune response, and the host–microbe interaction. In the case of cancer, the epithelium loses its barrier function and becomes prone to infections. Here, we show that intestinal tumors can alter the composition of the microbiome and that the microbiome can trigger a regenerative response in the tumor. We also show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome restores barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismal lifespan extension. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. It also provides a mechanistic understanding of the interplay between tumors and the microbiome in cancer progression. This work may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies to control tumorigenesis and restore host–microbe homeostasis. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death in this population. The development of therapies that can improve the response to chemotherapy in breast cancer patients is therefore of great importance. Here we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, and that this correlates with the expression of genes induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). We also show that targeting ROR1 with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can reduce the expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, inhibit the metastasis and repopulation of breast cancer PDXs, and improve the efficacy of chemotherapy in breast cancer patients. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may be a promising strategy for improving the response to chemotherapy in breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is controversial, with some studies suggesting that deglaciation began as early as 18.0 ka, whereas others suggest that deglaciation only began after 17.7 ka. We show that the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is linked to a volcanic eruption series that occurred at 17.7 ka. The volcanic eruptions led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which likely contributed to the changes in climate and circulation that led to accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation. This study provides a unique example of how volcanic eruptions can trigger climate changes that led to the end of the last ice age. This work also highlights the importance of volcanic eruptions in the history of the Earth system. (Show more)

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in assessments of global biodiversity and ecosystem services. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also find that inland fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, our analysis highlights the need to protect river ecosystems from the impacts of intensive fishing, particularly in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors. Our data can be used to inform environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes limits the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of Mo-based oxide are the key to achieve a high capacity and a low operating potential range. Furthermore, a hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized with LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2. This work combines a high capacity with a safe negative electrode material through delivering the Mo-based oxide with unique nanosized and metastable characters. This work provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. This work also provides a new strategy for the development of inherently safe energy devices. The ability to regenerate after injury is a key feature of the adult nervous system that has been lost in many other species. In the nematode C. elegans, the ability to regenerate is limited to a few neurons, and the molecular mechanisms that control this process are poorly understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway and is triggered by physical lesion of a sensory dendrite. We show that this form of regeneration is linked to a well-studied form of endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. These findings suggest that this form of regeneration represents a powerful platform for gene discovery in neuronal regeneration. Moreover, we note numerous similarities between this form of regeneration and conditioning of the adult nervous system to regenerate after injury. Taken as a whole, our study unites disparate forms of regeneration to uncover fresh molecular insights into activity-dependent control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity. (Show more)

The process of recombination is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity in populations and the evolution of new traits. In eukaryotes, recombination is initiated by the binding of proteins to specific DNA sequences. In this study, we describe the distribution of these binding sites across the genome of a flowering plant, and we find that they are concentrated in promoter regions of genes. We also find that the binding sites are more likely to be found in the 5′ untranslated region of genes than in the coding region. These results suggest that the binding sites of these proteins may be the basis for the initiation of recombination in plants. This work provides a foundation for understanding the evolution of recombination in plants. (Show more)

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis proposes that the brain is organized into functionally distinct networks, which are dynamically active in a context-dependent manner. This hypothesis has been tested using functional MRI, but the results have been controversial. We used metabolic PET to directly measure the resting state organization of the brain and found that the dominant RSN was topographically similar to the default mode network in healthy subjects. In Parkinson’s disease, the dominant RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during rest in healthy subjects and Parkinson’s disease patients, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This work provides a direct measure of the resting organization of the brain and its functional relevance. It also provides a method for assessing the impact of disease on the resting state organization of the brain. This approach can be extended to other neuroimaging modalities.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA that regulates translation. We report the discovery of a second 5′ modification in eukaryotes, the nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group. We find that NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. NAD-RNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally because NAD-RNA is also found on pre-mRNAs, and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. This 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. The discovery of this second 5′ modification in eukaryotes raises the possibility that it could regulate mRNA function in a manner similar to the eukaryotic mRNA cap.

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) was a landmark study that demonstrated the importance of glycemic control in preventing complications of type 1 and type 2 diabetes. The long-term follow-up of the DCCT participants, the Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study, has shown that glycemic control during the DCCT is associated with a reduced risk of complications. We found that DNA methylation at specific loci in blood cells from DCCT participants is associated with glycemia during the DCCT and that this association is maintained for several years after the DCCT. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. Our findings may also have implications for the treatment of type 2 diabetes.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and lacks effective treatment options. Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The mechanisms that underlie the development of alcohol dependence are not fully understood, but it is clear that the brain is involved in the disease. The gut microbiota has been shown to be altered in psychiatric disorders, which suggests the existence of a gut–brain axis. In the present study, we found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. (PsycINFO Database Record

The production of volatile compounds is a key feature of many plant species, and the biosynthesis of these compounds is of interest for both fundamental and applied reasons. In this study, we identify a gene essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We show that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce the diverse set of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of these compounds and will be of interest to researchers in the fields of plant biochemistry, flavor chemistry, and biotechnology.

The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is frequently investigated separately from other factors that may influence ecosystem performance. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. We found that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning becomes steeper as temperatures deviate from ambient conditions, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This result is driven by two processes linked to the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. First, more diverse communities have a greater chance of including species with thermal traits that enable them to maintain productivity as temperatures shift from ambient conditions. Second, we found a pronounced increase in the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect at high and low temperatures, indicating that changes in species interactions played a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. This is a major finding for the conservation of biodiversity and the sustainability of ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the MEC of freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are essential for place-cell encoding, are organized in a distinct manner from other cell types. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of MEC neurons and will be useful for understanding the functional role of MEC in navigation. This approach can be extended to study the organization of other cortical areas. The portability of the system will also enable studies in freely behaving animals in other species. This will be particularly useful for studying the organization of the neocortex, which is difficult to study in humans. The system is described in detail in the Methods section. Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of environmental and developmental signals. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not required for flowering of the host plant in a host–parasite interaction. Instead, FTs are able to signal between host and parasite plants to induce flowering. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the dodder parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also shows that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. Understanding the mechanisms of flowering regulation in host–parasite interactions may help to understand the evolution of flowering in plants. This study also illustrates the importance of photoperiod in flowering regulation.

The dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system is the primary circuit for the control of movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons of this system are integrated by specialized formations within the nigral system that likely play a role in the pathophysiology of Parkinson’s disease and other disorders. These findings suggest that the striosome–dendron bouquets are critical to the control of movement and motivation and may be important targets for therapeutic intervention.

We all have a sense of when two people are “clicking” or “not clicking.” But how do we know when two people are “clicking”? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Finally, we demonstrate that this signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected: Conversations with faster response times were perceived as more connected than the same conversations with slower response times. The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart and is responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, the sinoatrial (SAN) cells (SANCs), which are responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. The SAN cells are able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand by integrating information from the membrane clock and the Ca2+ clock. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1), a key component of store-operated Ca2+ entry, is selectively expressed in SANCs. Cardiac-specific deletion of STIM1 in mice resulted in depletion of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores of SANCs and led to SAN dysfunction, as was evident by a reduction in heart rate, sinus arrest, and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN.
