Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well established. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages and that it is essential for the expression of proinflammatory and antiinflammatory cytokines. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of macrophage activation. These findings may have implications for the treatment of inflammatory diseases. (Show more)

Language processing is a complex cognitive function that involves the ability to integrate and store information in working memory. The dominant view is that this is achieved through sustained, elevated neural activity. Here we propose an alternative account where memory is supported by intrinsic plasticity that downregulates neuronal firing rates. We show that this adaptive change in excitability can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant-based therapeutics. The delivery of functional biomolecules such as siRNA to plants is a major challenge due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Herein, we report a systematic assessment of DNA nanostructures for their ability to deliver siRNA across the cell wall and into plant cells. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are the key design parameters for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work provides a platform for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and opens up the possibility of developing plant-based therapeutics. (Show more)

Eutrophication is a major threat to the health of aquatic ecosystems worldwide, and it is driven largely by nonpoint nutrient loading from surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused almost exclusively on the largest watersheds, despite the fact that small tributaries are the most numerous and ubiquitous. We show that the 6 largest tributaries of Lake Michigan account for nearly 70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake, but that nutrient loads from small tributaries are high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. These findings suggest that small watersheds may play a greater role in driving coastal eutrophication than previously appreciated. Our results highlight the importance of small watersheds in the Anthropocene and the need to address nutrient management in these areas.

The ability to absorb work from its environment and convert it into chemical energy is a fundamental property of life. In this article, we study the dynamics of a simple chemical network that is exposed to an environment that makes strong thermodynamic forcing available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. Our results suggest that the environment may play a more important role in the dynamics of chemical networks than previously thought. They also provide a framework for the design of synthetic chemical systems that can absorb work from their environment and convert it into chemical energy. This work may have implications for the design of synthetic chemical systems that can absorb work from their environment and convert it into chemical energy.

The mechanisms by which antibodies against the N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor cause autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes in cortical microcircuitry can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. We validate a dynamic causal model of NMDAR-Ab effects on cortical microcircuitry and use this model to identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain EEG paroxysms in pediatric patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes render microcircuitry critically susceptible to overt EEG paroxysms when these key parameters are changed, even though the same parameter fluctuations are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. They also suggest that the same mechanisms that underlie the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in NMDAR-Ab encephalitis may underlie other forms of epilepsy. This may have important implications for the treatment of epilepsy. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, and it is important to understand how the system responded to abrupt warming in the past. We present a case study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a paleo-glacial state and was accompanied by a global C perturbation. We show that the warming event was accompanied by an injection of organic matter–derived C and anoxia, which were linked to a reduction in biodiversity. Earth system modeling indicates that the warming event was linked to enhanced nutrient fluxes and thermocline stratification. Our results highlight the importance of organic matter inputs and anoxia in the response of the Earth system to abrupt warming. They also highlight the potential for the Earth system to respond in a complex manner to rapid warming, which may have implications for our ability to predict the response to anthropogenic warming.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. Despite its popularity, the impact of RSPO certification on deforestation has not been quantified. We use a unique dataset of oil palm plantations in Indonesia to show that RSPO certification reduced deforestation by 33% from a counterfactual of 9.8 to 6.6% y−1. However, certification had no causal impact on deforestation in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results highlight the importance of rigorous monitoring and verification of certification claims. We also show that certification is not a panacea for tropical deforestation and that it is not a substitute for strong national policies and international commitments to reduce deforestation. Our findings suggest that the RSPO is not yet delivering on its promise to reduce tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a conserved protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 subunits, and the function of each subunit is not fully understood. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex is a major area of study. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes. In species with multiple sex determination alleles, however, sex determination is polygenic, resulting in multiple possible genotypes for sex. Here we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii, where two female- and two male-determining alleles interact to produce four possible sexes. We find that polygenic sex determination results in modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, including genital morphology, craniofacial morphology, gastrointestinal morphology, and home tank behaviors. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species- and light-generated photoproducts of lipids. These photoproducts, collectively known as “bisretinoids,” are oxidized to form highly damaging species that can lead to photoreceptor cell death. We show that the intracellular levels of iron impact the retina. We also show that the Fe chelator deferiprone decreases the oxidation and degradation of the bisretinoid A2E in the presence of light and protects retinal pigment epithelial cells from light-induced damage. These findings suggest that Fe levels impact the retina and that Fe chelation may be a useful strategy for the treatment of retinal diseases. (show more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystem functioning, and the specialization of their feeding strategies is a key factor in their success. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is often associated with morphological and functional changes throughout the organism. In this study, we show that specialization can evolve in a modular way, and that it is associated with specific morphological changes in the tentacles of siphonophores. Our results contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also help to build a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution.

The human hand is a complex and highly specialized structure. The fossil record of the evolution of the human hand is fragmentary, and the earliest hominin hand fossils are only 800,000 years old. We report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from West Turkana, Kenya, that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the modern human hand. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key derived feature and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This fossil also provides the earliest evidence for the use of the hand in the hominin lineage. The discovery of this fossil is part of a larger project to document the evolution of the human hand in the context of the evolution of the hominin fossil record. This project is supported by the National Science Foundation (DEB-1159955).

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key metabolic node in the biosynthesis of purine nucleotides. Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT that blocks tumor growth in mice. We also report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT that blocks tumor growth in mice. We show that the one-carbon donor formate rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These results suggest that SHMT inhibition is a promising strategy for cancer treatment. The importance of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not widely appreciated. This study shows that deforestation and forest fragmentation in rural Tanzania led to a reduction in fruit and vegetable consumption and thus vitamin A adequacy of diets. Conversely, forest fragmentation led to an increase in fruit and vegetable consumption and dietary vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using a modeling approach to test causal inferences, which is rarely done in the nutrition literature. The results of this study have implications for the design of future studies and the development of strategies to improve people’s diets in rural areas.

Modern farm machinery is the most important technological innovation of the 20th century, increasing agricultural productivity by a factor of 10. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
